note.p: Death: Constantinople, Ottoman Empire [Turkey], Europe (5 September 1680)
Burial Place: English cemetery, Constantinople; removed to the chapel of Christ's College Cambridge, England, Europe (where he shares a vault with Sir John Finch)
Education: Bishop's Stortford School; Christ's College, Cambridge (BA 1643; MA 1649); MD (Padua, incorporated at Cambridge 1661)

Career: Travelled abroad with Sir John Finch (1651); Professor of Music at Gresham College (1661-1680); Physician to British Embassy at Florence (1664-1670) and at Constantinople (1672-1680); with John Finch (FRS 1663) jointly founded two fellowships and two scholarships at Christ's College, Cambridge with a contribution of Â£2,000 each
Committee for examining the generation of insects (1661)
Other RSActivity: Tasked with enquiries into poisons while in Italy (1661);
Acted as a correspondent to the Society and its interests while abroad (1662);
Presented Cardinal Leopoldo de'Medici with the history of the Royal Society (1668)
Sources: Bulloch's Roll; DNB; Munk's Roll; Venn; ODNB [Sir John Finch]
References: R E W Maddison, 'The Accompt of William Balle from 28 November 1660 to 11 September 1663' in NR 1959 vol 14 pp 174-183

Notes: The election date is Baines' election date into the Society after the grant of the second charter in April 1663. All Fellows admitted in a two-month window after this charter, until 22 June 1663, are considered Original Fellows.
